Western Great Plains Mesquite Woodland and Shrubland

habitat_description:
Populations of the rose-bellied lizard occur from southern Texas through eastern and southern Mexico, Guatemala, and Belize into central Costa Rica (Bartlett and Bartlett 1999; Conant and Collins 1991; Mather and Sites 1985).
This species burrows in or using soil, decaying logs, hollow trees and stumps, and standing snag. In the United States, it occupies chaparral, hardwood woodland, and shrubland (Natureserve.org).

Nonetheless throughout its range, this species inhabits a variety of ecosystems. Populations occur in beaches and up to relatively high elevations. In Texas, it is associated with scrubby trees like mesquite. Also found on cacti, rocks, and fence posts (Bartlett and Bartlett 1999; Conant 1975; Fitch 1970). In Mexico, Guatemala, and Belize, it occurs in forest edges, clearings, Maya ruins, and savannas (Lee 2000; Natureserve.org).

Found in cacti, mesquite, and other scrubby flora associations.
